review.title: Variational Policy for Guiding Point Processes
review.abstract: Temporal point processes are powerful tools to model event occurrences and have a plethora of applications in social sciences. While the majority of prior works focus on the modeling and learning of these processes, we consider the problem of how to design the optimal control policy for general point process with stochastic intensities, such that the stochastic system driven by the process is steered to a target state. In particular, we exploit the novel insight from the information theoretic formulations of stochastic optimal control. We further propose a novel convex optimization framework and a highly efficient online algorithm to update the policy adaptively to the current system state. Experiments on synthetic and real-world data show that our algorithm can steer the user activities much more accurately than state-of-arts.

sections.text: In addition to previous work on stochastic optimal control, we are reviewing other work in the machine learning community. Some work focuses on the control of the process itself, but they are not generalizable for two reasons: (i) the processes are usually simple, such as the Poisson process (Brémaud, 1981) and a power-law decay function (Bayraktar & Ludkovski, 2014); (ii) the systems contain only the process of the point. However, in the social sciences, the system can be driven by many other stochastic processes, such as the Hawkes process and the Vienna process. Based on the Hawkes process, Farajtabar et al al al al al al. (2014) designs the basic intensity of behavior to achieve a stable state. Finally, we transform open loop policy into feedback policy and develop a scalable sample-based algorithm for calculating the guidelines.

sections.heading: 5.3 From Open-loop policy to feedback policy
sections.text: To design the feedback policy, we use the Model Predictive Control (MPC) scheme (Camacho & Alba, 2013), which uses the model of the process to predict the future evolution of the process to optimize the controller. In the MPC, online optimization and execution are intertwined as follows: (i) online optimization; at a certain point in time, a control policy is calculated using (18) for a short time horizon; (ii) apply the first optimal step u (t) at that time t and observe the new system state; (iii) feedback & repeat optimization; next time t + 1, with the new observed state, we recalculate the controller and repeat the above process.

sections.heading: 6.2 Experiments on Smart Broadcasting
sections.text: Experimental setup. We evaluate on a real Twitter dataset (Farajtabar et al., 2015), which contains 82,767 users with 322,666 tweets / retweets between September 21 and 30, 2012. For the stations, we track all followers and capture all tweets they have posted, and reconstruct the timelines of followers by collecting all tweets from people they follow. We first learn the parameters of the Poisson and Hawkes process, which capture each user's twitter behavior by maximizing the probability function (Karimi et al., 2016). We then select a station and get its competitors by selecting its followers and other stations that these followers follow. Using the parameters we learn, we simulate broadcast events on [0, 10] and divide them into 10 timestamps. We then execute control of the simulated dynamics. Appendix F contains details. The simulation repeats for 10 runs and we compare the cost of each state (4 different types of data).

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: We have presented the framework for controlling the stochastic intensity function of point processes, so that the nonlinear SDEs can be steered towards a target state. We use the novel view of determining an optimal probability measure induced by policy. We also offer a scalable algorithm with superior performance on various social problems. In addition, our framework can also tackle the traditional problems where the control lies in drift (Annex H contains details). Therefore, it offers one of the most general possibilities for stochastic optimal control. There are many interesting possibilities for future work. For example, we can apply our framework to other interesting problems such as influence maximization and activity design (Kempe et al., 2003).
